messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:13): ooh, am I being tentatively accused of FUD on public-html?

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:15): How did that get through?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:16): Maybe the process needs to be improved to prevent that from happening
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:16): and yesterday around 3 or 4
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:17): it's sad, though for sure the Process moguls can declare victory for now
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (16:21): I have GMail use nearly identical colors for whatwg, htmlwg, and webapps list emails, so I can't tell which is which without specifically looking for it.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:25): also, http://twitter.com/shelleypowers/status/8296745940 didn't last very long
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:26): And you are surprised why?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:28): you might upset the Process moguls

a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (16:49): is not holding his breath

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:54): Maybe the idea is to split the HTML5 language into as many tiny pieces as possible, and then you can block every one of the pieces except the tiny core that still has the name "HTML5" attached to it, and then you can claim you're not blocking HTML5
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (16:54): tks anyway....(wasn't *even* gonna include "accessible" in that question)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:55): can't think of any reasonable and common meaning of "HTML5" by which the 2D canvas context is not part of HTML5
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:57): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, you didn't finish your sentence on public-webapps
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:58): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, also, that test seems very pointless to optimize for

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:59): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: apparently Mozilla and Microsoft both thought it was sufficiently common to do getElementsByTagName in a loop that they optimized for it years before this test existed
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:01): (in fact, with caching it's not even that much of a perf hit to do it in a loop)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:01): exposing the gc seems very wrong
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:01): also you can optimize by creating small js objects
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:02): and doing other tricks
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:03): the overhead is in doing a GC allocation at all
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:03): there is no trick you can use to get the speed back
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): http://www.hotelgoal.com/city/vn/hotel-in-bai-chay.htm
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): for(i=0; i< document.getElementById(frm).getElementsByTagName('SELECT').length; i++){
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): if(document.getElementById(frm).getElementsByTagName('SELECT')[i].value==0){
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): Is that what the optimisation is for?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:06): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: there's only 4 select elements in that page afaict so the effect in this case would be small
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:06): It looks a very common pattern
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:06): http://www.esiweb.org/index.php?lang=fr&id=280&portrait_ID=66&function=print
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:07): while (document.getElementsByTagName("span")[i] != null) {
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:07): if (document.getElementsByTagName("span")[i].className
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:07): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, you don't think the gc issue is a problem?

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:08): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I dont think setting custom properties on NodeLists is at all common, so I don't think it's an issue in practice, even though it is theoretically nondeterministic behavior
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:08): we could forbid custom properties on nodelists

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:08): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: if we really wanted to avoid it, we could require returning the same object, which to the level of observational equivalence would require caching it so long as it is live, or if it has ever had a custom property set
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:09): but I don't think that is worth the effort
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:09): or pin objects
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:09): yeah
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:09): Lots seem to be looping over 'a' and 'img', so I imagine there's going to be quite a few of those
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:09): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: thanks for finding actual examples
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:10): See also http://google.com/codesearch?q=getElementsByTagName%5C%28%5B%5E%29%5D%2B%5C%29%5C%5B%5Ba-zA-Z%5D
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:10): it seems somewhat dangerous to me
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: clever search regexp
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:12): time for a beer
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:13): there is probably a small risk of depending on nondeterministic behavior in the unlikely case someone really does set custom properties
